entries.text: In Machiavelli’s political analysis, statecraft is treated not as abstract theory but as a practical condition shaping the durability of power.

The Prince reframes morality as contingent upon political survival, redefining virtue in terms of effectiveness rather than ethical purity.
In the Discourses on Livy, Machiavelli positions republican conflict as a productive engine of institutional resilience.
Machiavelli interprets Roman history as a laboratory for constitutional experimentation.
For Machiavelli, political founding often requires rupture with inherited norms.
